Placemark.name: Stop 1: Boston Common - 1634
Placemark.description:
Boston Common is the oldest public park in the United States. It was purchased by Boston's Puritan founders in 1634 from William Blaxton (Blackstone), the reclusive hermit and first white settler on the Shawmut peninsula (the Native American name for Boston). In 1630, Blaxton invited the Puritans, who were in search of a better water supply, to settle on the peninsula and share the water.
Free
The Common is a public park
Free
Official website (http://www.cityofboston.gov/freedomtrail/bostoncommon.asp)
617-536-4100
Handicap access: the park is generally accessible, but there are some steps at the exit to Beacon Street, which is required to access the State House, Freedom Trail Stop 2.
Restrooms are located in the Visitors Center, by Tremont Street
Public Transportation - Red or Green lines to the Park Street Station
Plan 1.5-2 hours to pass through security and take a tour.
Auto-translate link. (http://www.stevestravelguide.com/?p=1231)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Stop 2: State House - 1795 to 1797
Placemark.description:
Designed by Charles Bulfinch, the Massachusetts State House was started in 1795 and completed in 1797. It is located on land originally owned by John Hancock, whose house was on what is currently the State House west lawn (Hancock's house was torn down in 1863.)
The State House is the home to the Massachusetts legislative and executive offices and an outstanding piece of American history.
Free.
Access is via the General Hooker Entrance on the right side of the building. You will need to pass an airport-like security screening to enter the building.
Excellent free tours are offered. It is suggested that you make a reservation for the tour, although this is often not required.
Monday-Friday 10-4
Official website (http://www.sec.state.ma.us/trs/)
617 727-3676
Handicap access: most of the building is accessible via elevators. To enter, use the entrance at Ashburton Park.
Public transportation: Red or Green lines to the Park Street Station.
The tours run about 45 minutes and are worthwhile. Passing through security may take a little on busy days. Overall, plan about 1.5 hours for your visit.
Auto-translate link. (http://www.stevestravelguide.com/?p=1264)

Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Stop 3: Park Street Church - 1809
Placemark.description:
Founded in 1809, the Park Street Church was built on the site of original town granary. Famous as a bastion of human rights reform and social justice, the church hosted early anti-slavery lectures starting in 1823.
Free
Tours late June-August, Tuesday - Saturday 9 - 4
Website (http://www.parkstreet.org/tours) for tours
617-523-3283
Handicap access via elevator - requires staff to be alerted.
Public Transportation: Red or Green lines to the Park Street Station
Auto-translate link. (http://www.stevestravelguide.com/?p=1274)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Stop 4: Granary Burying Ground - 1660
Placemark.description:
Founded in 1660, the Granary Burying Ground is the third oldest burying ground in Boston, developed when the King's Chapel Burying Ground was reaching capacity. It is the final resting place for many of the most important Revolutionary-era personalities including three signers of the Declaration of Independence (John Hancock, Sam Adams and Robert Treat Paine), nine Massachusetts governors, Paul Revere, the Boston Massacre Victims, Ben Franklin's parents and even Mother Goose.
Free
Open daily 9 AM - 5 PM
Official website (http://www.cityofboston.gov/freedomtrail/granary.asp)
617-635-4505
Handicap access is via a ground entrance at the end of Tremont Place. Go past the Tremont Street entrance, turn left on Beacon Street and left into alley. Enter throught the gate on the right at the end of the alley.
No restrooms.

Public Transportation: Red or Green lines to the Park Street Station.
Auto-translate link. (http://www.stevestravelguide.com/?p=1280)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Stop 5: King's Chapel - 1689 / 1754
Placemark.description:
The first King's Chapel, a small wooden structure, was completed at this site in 1688 as home for the first Anglican congregation in Boston.
The current granite church was built in 1754 when the original was outgrown. It was erected around the original wooden church so as to not disrupt services. When the building was finished, the old church was broken up and removed through the windows.
Free, but there is a charge for crypt or tower tour.
Summer: Mon. Thu. Fri. Sat. 10 - 4 Winter: Sat. 10
Summer: Mon. Thu. Fri. Sat. 10 - 4 Winter: Sat. 10
Official website (http://www.kings-chapel.org/index.html)
617-523-1749
Handicap access: 2.5" sill at the entrance, otherwise accessible.
Public Transportation: Red or Green lines to the Park Street Station. Alternative Red or Green lines to Government Center.
Auto-translate link. (http://www.stevestravelguide.com/?p=1304)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Stop 5a: King's Chapel Burying Ground - 1630
Placemark.description:
The King's Chapel Burying Ground is the oldest burying ground in Boston. It is the final resting place for William Dawes (the other rider on Paul Revere's Midnight Ride), John Winthrop (the Puritan leader at the founding of Boston in 1630), and others. There are many beautiful old headstones.

Free
Open daily 9 - 5
617-635-4505
Auto-translate link. (http://www.stevestravelguide.com/?p=1307)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Stop 6: Boston Latin, Old City Hall - 1635 / 1865
Placemark.description:
Site of the Boston Latin School, the first school in the United States, founded in 1635.
The school was originally at the site of the Ben Franklin statue, which is the oldest portrait statue in the US. Also at this site is the Old City Hall, built between 1862 and 1865, which served as Boston City Hall until 1969.
Free - everything is outside
Public Transportation: Red, Silver or Orange lines to Downtown Crossing.
Plan for 5-10 minutes to see the statues and plaques.
Auto-translate link. (http://www.stevestravelguide.com/?p=1315)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Stop 7: Old Corner Book Store - 1711
Placemark.description:
This was originally the site of the home of the outspoken Quaker Anne Hutchinson, who was banished from Boston in 1637. Hutchinson lived there from 1634 until her banishment. That house burned during the great fire in 1711.
The current house was built in 1711 and was originally an apothecary. It became a bookstore and printing shop in 1828. Between 1833 and 1864 under Ticknor and Fields, it became the nation's leading publisher, producing works by Longfellow, Stowe, Hawthorne, Emerson, and Dickens.

Wiki more information (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_Corner_Bookstore)
Auto-translate link. (http://www.stevestravelguide.com/?p=1318)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Stop 8: Old South Meeting House - 1729
Placemark.description:
In 1669, a group of Pilgrim dissenters from Boston's First Church built their first meeting house on this site. In 1729, when that building was outgrown, the current brick structure was erected.
Throughout the Colonial period, Old South was Boston's largest building. Meetings too large for Faneuil Hall were held here. It was the site of many important Patriot gatherings including the meeting that immediately preceded the Boston Tea Party in 1770. At that meeting, 5,000 townspeople (1/3 of Boston's population) heard Sam Adams say "Gentlemen, this meeting can do nothing more to save the country." Legend says this was the signal for 100 Patriots dressed as Native Americans to march to Boston harbor and begin the Boston Tea Party.

Old South was so emblematic of the Rebel cause that when the British occupied Boston during 1775-6, they gutted it, filled it with dirt and used to practice horseback riding.
AAA/WGBH discount
Open Daily all year.
April 1 - October 31 9:30 - 5November 1 - March 31 10 - 4
Closed Thanksgiving, Christmas Eve Day, Christmas, and New Year's Day.
Official website (http://www.oldsouthmeetinghouse.org/default.aspx)
617-482-6439
Handicap access: wheelchair accessible, listening devices available
Public transportation: State Street (Blue/Orange Lines), Government Center (Green Line) and Downtown Crossing (Red Line).
Auto-translate link. (http://www.stevestravelguide.com/?p=1321)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Stop 9: Old State House - 1713
Placemark.description:
The Old State House (1713) is the oldest surviving public building in Boston, and was the seat of the state's legislature until 1798. It was the site of many important Revolutionary-era events.
The current building replaced the First Town-House (built on this site between 1657-68), which burned down in the great fire of 1711.
It is now the home of the Bostonian Society and houses an excellent museum and programs.
Open daily, 9 - 5, January 9 - 4, July and August 9- 6 Closed New Year's, Thanksgiving, and Christmas
Admission $7.50, Seniors & Students $6 Children (6-18) $3
Official website (http://www.bostonhistory.org/)
(617) 720-1713
The Old State house is not considered wheelchair accessible. There are plans to address this, but please call to confirm.
Public transportation: Orange or Blue lines to State Street. Alternative, Green line to Government Center, or Red line to Downtown Crossing.
The talks given by museum personnel are excellent and run 20-30 minutes covering subjects such as the Boston Massacre and Old State House History. The museum has interesting collections. Plan an hour for your visit.
Auto-translate link. (http://www.stevestravelguide.com/?p=1328)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Stop 10: Boston Massacre Site - 1770
Placemark.description:
This was the site of the Boston Massacre, which took place on March 5, 1770. The Massacre took place after an unfortunate chain of events led British soldiers to fire on an angry Boston mob, killing five and wounding six. Although hardly a massacre (most of the soldiers were later acquitted of blame), it was to be an important propaganda event in provoking Colonial unrest.
There is a plaque on the ground, just beneath the balcony of the Old State House, that marks the site.
Auto-translate link. (http://www.stevestravelguide.com/?p=1332)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Stop 11: Fanueil Hall 1742 / 1805
Placemark.description:
Faneuil Hall was built and given to the town by wealthy merchant Peter Faneuil in 1742. In 1805, based on a Charles Bulfinch design, it was expanded and a third floor was added.
Referred to as the "Cradle of Liberty," it was host to many important Revolutionary-era meetings and events including speeches by James Otis and Sam Adams, the establishment of the first Committee of Correspondence, and the first meeting to protest the tea tax that led to the Boston Tea Party.
Free
Open daily, 9-5; ranger-led historical talks every thirty minutes. This is also home to the new National Park Service vistor center - an excellent place to plan your Freedom Trail visit.
Official website (http://www.nps.gov/bost/historyculture/fh.htm)
617-242-5642
Handicap elevators in the visitor center.
Public transportation: Green or Blue line to Government Center. The Ancient & Honorable Artillery Company (http://www.ahac.us.com/), the oldest chartered military organization in North America has a museum on the 3rd floor.
Auto-translate link. (http://www.stevestravelguide.com/?p=1338)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Stop 12: Paul Revere House - 1680
Placemark.description:
Dating from 1680, this is oldest remaining structure in Boston. It was home to Paul Revere from 1770 - 1800.
It is located in North Square, which was the center of activity in the 18th century North End.

Adults $3.50, Seniors and College Students $3, Children (5-17) $1
Open Daily April 15 - October 31 - 9:30 - 5:15; November 1 - April 14 - 9:30 - 4:15; Closed on Mondays in January, February and March; Closed on Thanksgiving, Christmas Day and New Year's Day.
Official website (http://www.paulreverehouse.org/)
(617) 523-2338
Handicap accessible first floor, ask at ticket booth for a temporary ramp.
No restrooms
Public transportation: Green or Orange line to Haymarket Station.
Auto-translate link. (http://www.stevestravelguide.com/?p=1346)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Stop 13: Old North Church - 1723
Placemark.description:
Officially known as Christ's Church, Old North was built in 1723 and is the oldest standing church in Boston.
In April, 1775, it was the sight of the hanging lanterns that notified Patriots in Charlestown that the British were leaving "two if by sea" prior to Paul Revere's Midnight Ride and the Battles at Lexington and Concord.
Free (donation)
Open:
January–February: 10– 4pm, Tues – Sunday
March–May: 9 - 5 daily
June–October: 9 – 6 daily
November–December: 10 – 6 daily
Sunday services 9 and 11 AM
Official website (http://www.oldnorth.com/)
617-523-6676
Handicap access - 1/2" step at entrance to church; gift shop limited.
No restrooms
Public transportation: Green or Orange line to Haymarket Station.
Auto-translate link. (http://www.stevestravelguide.com/?p=1352)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Stop 14: Copp's Hill Burying Ground - 1659
Placemark.description:
Copp's Hill Burying Ground was founded in 1659. Famous Bostonians resting here include the Puritan ministers Increase and Cotton Mather, Robert Newman, the patriot who hung the lanterns that signaled "two if by sea" in Old North Church, and Prince Hall, the father of Black Freemasonry.
The British mounted cannon on Copp's Hill that that were used to bombard Charlestown during the Battle of Bunker Hill.
Free - public park
Official website (http://www.cityofboston.gov/parks/hbgi/CoppsHill.asp)
617-961-3034
Handicap access limited as it is up a steep hill from Old North Church and there are several steep granite steps up to burying ground
No restrooms
Public transportation: Green or Orange line to North Station.
Auto-translate link. (http://www.stevestravelguide.com/?p=1357)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Stop 15: USS Constitution - 1797
Placemark.description:
USS Constitution, launched in 1797, is the oldest commissioned warship afloat in the world.
The USS Constitution was involved in 33 fights, and never lost. The most famous, and the one that gave her the name "Old Ironsides," was with British Frigate HMS Guerriere in the War of 1812. During that engagement, cannonballs fired at the USS Constitution bounced off as if she were made of iron.
Free - must show valid ID to visit ship
Nov. 1- March 31 Thurs - Sun 10 - 4.
April 1- Sept. 30 Tues - Sun 10 - 6.
Oct. 1- Oct. 31 Tues - Sunday 10 - 4
Wait required to take the worthwhile tour.
Closed for Martin Luther King Jr.'s Birthday, President's Day, Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Years
Official website from NPS (http://www.nps.gov/bost/historyculture/ussconst.htm)
Official USS Constitution website (http://www.history.navy.mil/ussconstitution/index.html)
617-242-5670
Handicap access via ramped gangplank to main deck, but deck has 1/2" raised ridges. Navy personnel can assist. Lower decks are down steep staircases.
Restrooms are in the Visitors Center.
Public transportation: Green or Orange line to North Station. Alternative, 93 Bus to Sullivan Station Bunker Hill
Also visit the wonderful USS Constituion Museum across the dock as well as the WWII destroyer, Cassin Young.
Auto-translate link. (http://www.stevestravelguide.com/?p=1362)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Charlestown Navy Yard - 1800
Placemark.description:
The Charlestown Navy Yard was established in 1800 as one of the first official Navy facilities in the United States. It ceased to be an active operations center in 1974.
Today it is the site of the USS Constitution, the USS Cassin Young one of the first two dry docks in the US, and has a wonderful museum.
Great fun. Plan for a several hour visit.

Official website (http://www.nps.gov/bost/historyculture/cny.htm)
Official Charlestown Navy Yard website (http://www.charlestownonline.net/navyyard.htm)
NPS Maritime History website (http://www.nps.gov/nr/travel/maritime/bns.htm)
Auto-translate link. (http://www.stevestravelguide.com/?p=1375)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Stop 16: Bunker Hill Monument - 1775/1843
Placemark.description:
The monument is located on Breed's Hill at the site of the Patriot redoubt during the Battle of Bunker Hill, which was fought on June 17, 1775. The monument was dedicated in 1843.
Free
Daily 9 - 5; last climb at 4:30
July - August 9 - 6; last climb at 5:30
Official website (http://www.nps.gov/bost/historyculture/bhm.htm) 617-242-5641
Handicap access to lodge next to monument via a ramp. Monument has 294 steps to the top.
Restrooms in the lodge.
The Bunker Hill Museum (across the street), is fully accessible with elevators and restrooms.
Museum website (http://www.nps.gov/bost/historyculture/bhmuseum.htm).
Auto-translate link (http://www.stevestravelguide.com/?p=1370).
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Central Burying Ground - 1756
Placemark.description:
The Central Burying Ground is one of the oldest burying grounds in Boston. It is the last resting place for the remains of Gilbert Stuart (painter of George Washington (http://www.stevestravelguide.com/paul-revere-and-george-washington-face-to-face-at-boston-mfa.html)) and many who died during the Battle of Bunker Hill.
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Parkman Bandstand
Placemark.description:
TheParkman Bandstand was built in 1912 in honor of George Parkman, who had willed$5 million to the parks of Boston. Theland where it sits was originally Cow (or Horse) Pond – which was filled in aftercattle grazing on the Common was prohibited in 1830.
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Frog Pond and Tadpole Playground
Placemark.description:
Great place for skating in the winter and playing in the summer. Young children will enjoy the Tadpole playground.

Official Frog Pond website (http://www.bostonfrogpond.com/)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Soldiers and Sailors Monument
Placemark.description:
TheSoldiers and Sailors Monument is on top of Flagstaff Hill, the tallest hill inthe Common. Completed in 1877, it honors troops that perished in the CivilWar.
Themonument is 126 feet high and carved from white granite. There are fournoteworthy bas-relief tablets at the base. The column istopped by a female figure titled "America" wearing a crown of thirteen starsand holding the United States flag, a sword, and a laurel wreath in her hands.

Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Robert Gould Shaw & MA 54th Memorial
Placemark.description:
A beautiful Augustus Saint-Gaudens' haunting sculpture that memorializes Robert Gould Shaw and the Massachusetts 54th Regiment. Shaw was the son of a wealthy Boston family. He led the 54th, one of the first African American units to fight in the Civil War. Shaw died (along with 74 enlisted men and 3 officers) leading an assault on Fort Wagner, South Carolina in 1863. Sergeant William H. Carney, who was severely wounded, saved the regiment’s flag from being captured. Carney was the first African American to be awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor.
Official website (http://www.nps.gov/boaf/historyculture/shaw.htm)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Site of Spring that Led to Boston's Founding
Placemark.description:
John Winthrop's Pilgrim's were invited by William Blaxton to move from Charlestown to Shawmut (Boston) because of an excellent water source. Here was the site of the Spring that Blaxton referenced. It is now concreted over, but it is still running.
By Spring Lane
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Benjamin Franklin Statue
Placemark.description:
Oldest portrait statue in the US, placed here in 1856. By Old City Hall.
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Irish Famine Memorial
Placemark.description:
Memorializes the Great Irish Famine, which took place between 1845 and 1852. Many Irishmen emigrated to Boston, settling originally in the North End.
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Site of Benjamin Franklin's Birthplace
Placemark.description:
Site of Benjamin Franklin's birth in 1706.
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Quincy Market - 1826
Placemark.description:
Quincy Market was built between 1824 and 1826 to provide additional market capacity for Faneuil Hall. It is named in honor of the then mayor, Josiah Quincy. At the time of its construction, it was at the harbor's edge. Quincy Market was initially a foodstuff and produce shopping center. The North Market and South Market buildings, which are immediately flanking Quincy Market, were built in the mid 1800's.
By the middle 1970's the whole area had deteriorated. It was revitalized as part of the preparations for the Bicentennial, in 1976. Today, it is one of the busiest tourist destinations in Boston.
Website for Faneuil Hall Marketplace (http://www.faneuilhallmarketplace.com/)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Samuel Adams / 1630 Water Line
Placemark.description:
Sam Adams statue behind Faneuil Hall.
The site of the original harbor water line from 1630 - all the land from here to the harbor is landfill.
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Ebenezer Hancock House - 1767 & The Boston Stone - 1737
Placemark.description:
The Ebenezer Hancock House was built in 1767 by John Hancock's uncle. John inherited it and gave it to his brother Ebenezer, later the deputy paymaster of the Continental Army during the Revolution.

The Boston Stone, directly across from Ebenezer's house, has been a landmark since 1737. A painter, brought the stone from England to grind pigments prior to 1700. According to legend, it has served as the "zero milestone," for measuring official distance to Boston.
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: New England Holocaust Memorial
Placemark.description:
Initiated by survivors of the Nazi concentration camps, the New England Holocaust Memorial is a moving and haunting reminder of one of the great tragedies of our time.
A chance to pause and reflect.
Official website (http://www.nehm.org/intro.html)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: North Square & Site of Second Church
Placemark.description:
The North Square was the center of the NorthEnd life and commerce during Colonial times and the site of some of the town's mostimpressive mansions. It was also the location for the Second Meeting House(Church), which was built in 1649 and was presided over by Puritan ministersCotton and Increase Mather.
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: USS Constitution Museum
Placemark.description:
A wonderful museum in the Charlestown Navy Yard.
Great collections of information to make the USS Constitution come alive.
Free (donation)
Official website (http://www.ussconstitutionmuseum.org/)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: USS Cassin Young - 1943
Placemark.description:
WWII destroyer commissioned in 1943.
Great fun for kids of all ages.
Free
Open 9-5 daily. Closed Christmas, New Year's day and Thanksgiving
NPS website (http://www.nps.gov/bost/historyculture/usscassinyoung.htm)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Dry Dock 1 - 1827
Placemark.description:
Built in 1827, this is one of the first two naval dry docks in the United States.
Fascinating interpretive displays.
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Bunker Hill Museum
Placemark.description:
Excellent museum at the foot of the Bunker Hill Monument. There are National Park Service guides and interpretive programs.

Free
Official website (http://www.nps.gov/bost/historyculture/bhmuseum.htm)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Boston Tea Party Ship Museum
Placemark.description:
Site of the Boston Tea Party Ship Museum.
Admission: $25 adult, $15 child. Various pre-visit purchase specials available online.

Official website. (http://www.bostonteapartyship.com/)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Garden Court Street
Placemark.description:
Garden Court Street was the site of the Clark-Frankland and Thomas Hutchinson mansions.
Hutchinson's mansion was gutted as part of a protest of the Stamp Act in 1765. Both were torn down in 1834 as part of street widening.
Rose Fitzgerald (Kennedy). the mother of President John F. Kennedy, was born at 2 Garden Court Street in 1890.
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Saint Stephen's Church - 1804
Placemark.description:
Saint Stevens is the last remaining Bulfinch church in Boston. Originally, it was called New North Church and was Unitarian.

Sold to a Roman Catholic parish in 1862, it was the site of Rose Fitzgerald's (Kennedy) baptism in 1890.
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Cyrus Dallin's Paul Revere Monument
Placemark.description:
Unveiled in 1940, this is one of the most photographed sculptures in Boston. It was begun by Cyrus Dallin 1883, when he won a competition for the commission. This is likely the 8th version of the sculpture.

Website for Cyrus Dallin (http://dallin.org/)
Post on the Dallin Museum (http://www.stevestravelguide.com/?s=cyrus)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Paul Revere Mall
Placemark.description:
Created in 1933 and known as The Prado by locals, it is a brick passage / park that leads from Hanover Street to the Old North Church. The mall walls are lined with bronze plaques that commemorate famous North Enders.
It can provide a quiet place to sit if you need a break from the hysteria of touring.
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Clough House - 1712
Placemark.description:
One of the oldest homes remaining in Boston. It was home to Ebenezer Clough, a master mason who helped build Old North (Christ's) Church. This is representative of many houses that once made up this neighborhood. There is a great old printing museum on the first floor - check to see if it is open.
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Narrowest House in Boston
Placemark.description:
OK, not really Revolutionary, but....
it is 10.4 feet (3.16m) at it's widest, it tapers to 9.2 (2.82 m) feet at the back. It was allegedly built as a "spite house" a little after 1874. Boston real estate is expensive, but there should be limits.

Wikipedia site (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skinny_House_(Boston))
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Cafe Marliave - 1875 / Province House Steps - 1679
Placemark.description:
The oldest Italian restaurant in Boston, the Marliave dates from 1875. It has pleasant outside seating for the summer months.
It located right above the site of the Province House Steps (1679–1864). The Province House was the official govenors residence during the Revolutionary Period.

Website (http://marliave.com/home/) 617-422-0004
Province House Wiki (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Province_House_(Boston,_Massachusetts))
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Durgin Park - 1827
Placemark.description:
This iconic restaurant has been around since 1827. Famous for old Yankee recipes, it is a real flash from the past and one of the oldest places you can dine in Boston. Diners are seated at long tables with other patrons. A lot of fun.
Official website (http://www.arkrestaurants.com/durgin_park.html).
617-227-2038
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Union Oyster House - 1713/1742/1826
Placemark.description:
The Union Oyster House, which started serving in 1826, is the oldest continuously operating restaurant in the US. The building started operations as a dress shop and dates from 1742, although other sources date it to as early as 1713.. At that time, the harbor actually came up to the dress shop's back door.
The Oyster Bar at the front of the restaurant is legend - regular Daniel Webster daily drank a tall tumbler of brandy and water with each half-dozen oysters, usually eating at least six plates.

Offical website (http://www.unionoysterhouse.com/)
617-227-2750
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Green Dragon Tavern - 1654
Placemark.description:
The original Green Dragon Tavern (around the corner at 84 Union Street) was founded in 1654 and an active pub by 1714. It was torn down in 1828. The Green Dragon was a regular haunt for the Sons of Liberty and the site of the planning meetings for the Boston Tea Party.
The current incarnation is fun and boasts decent bar food.
Website (http://www.somerspubs.com/green-dragon.html) 617-237-2114
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Chart House - John Hancock's Counting House - 1730
Placemark.description:
Currently the Chart House restaurant, this was originally the Gardiner House, built around 1760. It was later John Hancock's "counting house" (business office). It is a wonderful historic building with outside seating and great view of the harbor.
Official website (http://www.chart-house.com/)
617-227-1576
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Warren Tavern - 1780
Placemark.description:
Built in 1780, it was reportedly the first building raised after the British burned Charlestown during the Battle of Bunker Hill in 1775. It is named for Dr./General Joseph Warren, the famous Patriot, killed at Bunker Hill. It was visited by George Washington, Paul Revere, and Benjamin Franklin.
Good pub food, great slice of history.
Official website (http://warrentavern.com/)
617-241-8142
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Mikes Pastry
Placemark.description:
OK, its not historic, but the lines mean something. Pick up a pastry and wander over to Paul Revere Mall and enjoy. More types of cannoli than you can imagine!
Website (http://www.mikespastry.com/index.html)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Galleria Umberto
Placemark.description:
Galleria Umberto, for pizza-oriented lunch fare, is very popular with the locals. 289 Hanover Street
(617) 227-5709
Yelp website (http://www.yelp.com/biz/galleria-umberto-boston)(They do not have their own web site.)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Pizzeria Regina - The Original
Placemark.description:
Pizzeria Regina, Boston’s oldest pizzeria and one of the oldest in the US has been here since 1926. The chain started at this location - this is much better than the branches.
Be prepared to wait in the evenings.
11 1/2 Thacher Street.
617-227-0765
Website (http://www.reginapizzeria.com/location_detail.php?location_id=38&Brick%20Oven%20Pizza%20-%20North%20End%20-%20The%20Original%20-%20Boston%20-%20Boston)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: La Summa
Placemark.description:
La Summa, old world (not trendy) Italian, but very nice. Excellent for lunch or dinner. 30 Fleet St
617-523-9503
Website (http://lasumma.com/)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Modern Pastry
Placemark.description:
Modern Pastry at 257 Hanover Street
Great, and often less crowed alternative to Mike's across the street. Does not have seating.
617-523-3783
Website (http://www.modernpastry.com/)
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: 1st Bullfinch Otis House
Placemark.description:
The first mansion designed by Charles Bulfinch for Harrison Grey Otis.
141 Cambridge Street
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: 2nd Bulfinch Otis House
Placemark.description:
Second Mansion designed by Charles Bulfinch for Harrison Grey Otis
85 Mt. Vernon Street, on Beacon Hill
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: 3rd Bulfinch Otis House
Placemark.description:
The third Harrison Grey Otis mansion designed by Charles Bulfinch.
At 45 Beacon Street.
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Charles Street Meeting House
Placemark.description:
Asher Benjamin designed Charles Street Meeting House, built between 1804-7.
It was originally the Third Baptist Church, which used the Charles River for its baptisms.
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Water Shuttle Landing - Charlestown Navy Yard
Placemark.description:
Water Shuttle Landing for inner harbor trip to Long Wharf. A beautiful ride on a nice day.

MBTA Schedule (http://www.mbta.com/schedules_and_maps/boats/lines/?route=F4).
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Water Shuttle Landing - Long Wharf
Placemark.description:
Water Shuttle landing for inner harbor trip to the Charlestown Navy Yard. A beautiful ride on a nice day.

MBTA Schedule (http://www.mbta.com/schedules_and_maps/boats/lines/?route=F4).
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!

Placemark.name: Acorn Street - Most Photographed in Boston
Placemark.description:
Acorn Street dates from the 1820's and is the most photographed street in Boston. A must stop on your hike of Beacon Hill.
Download the Guide from Amazon (http://www.amazon.com/Freedom-Trail-Boston-Ultimate-ebook/dp/B008H45KQA/ref=tmm_kin_title_0?ie=UTF8&qid=1349537507&sr=1-1)!
